title: Man says he's now impotent after penis 'mutilated' to fix 'month-long' erection
text:

A Viagra user has been left impotent after doctors 'mutilated' his penis while trying to put down his month-long erection.

Nat Thind, 26, said his ordeal started after he bought a Viagra pill over the counter in June, having previously used the drug several times in the past without any problems.

When his erection failed to subside he went to the doctors, who diagnosed him with priapism, a condition involving a painful erection that will not go down.

After two failed attempts to drain his member with needles, medics resorted to cutting his penis with a blade to let the blood leak out, however this proved ineffective.

(Image: Tom Wren SWNS)

(Image: Nat Thind SWNS)

Mr Thind's penis finally returned to a flaccid state naturally, however he is now incapable of achieving an erection, something he has described as his 'dark secret'.

He wrote on his GoFundMe page: "I went to A&E and they tried to treat it, however not successfully.

"In the months following and through speaking to other doctors, I have found that they did not really know what they were doing and it turns out they just 'had a go'.

(Image: Nat Thind SWNS)

(Image: Tom Wren SWNS)

"As a result I am now left with a mutilated penis, a numb tip, the inability to get an erection or achieve orgasm, random shooting & burning pains and penile fibrosis.

"Going from having a healthy sex life to no sex life is devastating and is taking its toll on relationships. It is most definitely not easy living with this dark secret that I feel so ashamed of."

Mr Thind, from Havant, Hampshire, said doctors in Ghent, Belgium, and Munich, Germany, confirmed he had nerve damage.

(Image: Getty Images/iStockphoto)

(Image: Tom Wren SWNS)

He has undergone a minor operation which he hopes will fix his problem, although it is too early to know whether it has been successful.

The electrician told The Star : "It’s very difficult to come to terms with the fact things aren’t working as they should.

"It’s particularly difficult to deal with as someone who’s only 26 years old and otherwise fit.

"(But) there’s no point in me being depressed about what’s happened."
description: Nat Thind, from Havant, Hampshire, said his inability to get an erection has become his 'dark secret'
